bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, May 28, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg supplies Hench with details on the upcoming unveiling of the Cornwell painting. He discusses Law's introduction of Hench, the guest list, Hench's speech, the planned order of proceedings, and the painting.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, May 28, 1941
div1.opener:
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N. J.
May 28, 1941.
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench,
div1.p:
You are quite right about my neglecting to tell you many essential
details concerning this luncheon. I hope that I cleared up most of
your questions this morning on the 'phone. After talking with you I
talked with Mr. Law at Philadelphia and he told me that all he expected
to say about the series of paintings, “Pioneers of American Medicine”
would be as follows:

“Some years ago John Wyeth and Brother felt that they would like to
make some contribution to the general knowledge of medicine outside
the ordinary field in which pharmaceutical houses function. It had
been noted that every school child and the man in the street is
quite conscious of the contribution made by European scientiests
like Lister, Pasteur and the Curies. However, very few Americans
had ever heard of Dr. William Beaumont, McDowell, and Trudeau.

We felt that we could make a contribution in the form of a pictorial
study of the contributions of American medicine.

Today I have asked you to join me in inveiling what is really a pre-
view of the third painting in the series, “Pioneers of American Medi-
cine” We have with us a gentleman who is a physician who has contri-
buted much to the success which we hope this painting will enjoy.
This doctor who stands high in his profession cannot rest in the
manner of ordinary men. Some four years ago when he went to Cuba on
a vacation of two or three weeks he decided that he might improve his
time in some manner and his first thought was to see the locale of
the yellow fever investigation which took place near Havana in 1900.

His interest and some of the historical facts which he discovered he
will tell you himself. It is sufficient for me to say that his in-
terest in the yellow fever investigation has grown into an absorbing
hobby. He may write a book on what he has learned. He could write
two of them.

Not long after Mr Cornwell began work on the present painting this
outstanding physician-historian kindly consented to aid Mr. Cornwell
in developing the editorial theme of the painting. Since that time
he has contributed invaluable information and advice. He was not
satisfied merely to give us his own opinion and referred us to more than
a dozen of the people previously unknown to Mr. Cornwell who had actu-
ally been in contact with the yellow fever board during the time this
Dr. Hench
-2-
May 28, 1941
this work was being done. I wish to introduce to you our speaker
for this occasion, Dr. Philip S. Hench, of the Mayo Clinic.”

This is not exactly what Mr. Law will say, of course, but it is the
impression which I gathered from his telephone conversation of this morn-
ing, and I told him I would send it to you so that you may know what to
expect.

I wish to review for you the names of certain persons who have ac-
cepted Mr Law's invitation:
Mrs. Reed
Mr. Kissinger
Dr. Eben J. Carey, Dean
Marquette University Medical School
Dr. Vincent W. Archer,
University of Virginia
Dr. Harvey E. Jordan, Dean
University of Virginia Medical School
Major-General Ireland
Mr. Cornwell
Mr. Wm. S. Milliken, Director
Cleveland Art Museum
Dr. Nathan Van Etten, President,
American Medical Ass'sn.
Dr. Parkinson, Dean
Temple University Medical School

There is a numerous list of physicians whose names would probably mean
nothing to you at the moment. Others who have been invited and from whom
we have not had time to receive acceptances include the editors of three
Cleveland newspapers, four of the better known science writers from New
York and Washington, the Cleveland representatives of the Associated and
United Press Services and a miscellaneous group of newspaper men numbering
about a dozen; the Mayor of the City of Cleveland; the Superintendent of
Schools, the President of Western Reserve University; the directors and
presidents of half a dozen art associations and galleries. My prediction
is that there will be about seventy-five present but we will have to wait
until tomorrow to make an accurate estimate.

In confirmation of our conversation of this morning I think you are
quite right in borrowing from your Lazear dedication talk, your copy of
which I am returning herewith. I don't think that twenty minutes is too
long for your address as I believe the people who will be at this meeting
are for the most part there because they are interested in the story you
have to tell.

In talking with Mr. Law we decided to arrange the order of procedure
as follows:
1. Introduction by Mr. Law
2. Address by Dr. Hench
3. Introduction of Major General Ireland by Mr. Law (It is presumed
that you will have mentioned to the audience that Gen Ireland
is present.)
4. An impromptu speech by Gen. Ireland, which may include the read-
ing of one of the letters supplied by Mrs. Reed if you think
there is one which is appropriate. (After looking them over I
don't feel very optimistic on this.)
Dr. Hench
-3-
May 28, 1941
5. Introduction of Mr. Kissinger by Mr. Law (I will have coached
Mr. Kissinger that all he is expected to say is that he is
pleased to be there in honor of Major Reed.)
6. Introduction of Mrs. Reed by Mr Law which will include the
request that Mrs. Reed unveil the painting. Mrs. Reed does
not wish to speak, so she says. (In a private party she is
an inveterate talker and admits it. In fact, she boasts
about it, all in fun.)
The painting will be covered by a silk cloth to which ribbons are
attached and will require a slight jerk to have the cloth fall to the
floor and reveal the picture.
(Space for applause.)
7. Mr. Law will introduce Mr. Cornwell, asking him to say a few
words regarding the technical problems of painting such a
picture.

This I believe, as done in Mr. Cornwell's customary manner, will
add much to the interest of the occasion and help cover his embarrass-
ment in that the painting is not complete in all details. Incidentally,
a lesser artist would have slapped the picture togeher so that it would
have been complete for the occasion on Monday, but Mr. Cornwell's em-
barking on a project of this nature leaves time without meaning. In the
long run, while it may inconvenience us somewhat that the work is not
done on schedule, John Wyeth and Brother are certainly better off. We
will get much more of the artist's time and attention for our money than
we originally planned.
The foregoing events will end the unveiling.

In answer to additional auestions, the Reed, Lazear, Finlay, Moran,
and Kissinger portraits are complete. The faces and figures of Trudy,
Wood, Cook and Kean are sketched in. He did a nice head of a Cuban in
the group composed of private soldiers. Cornwell would prefer to have
the two men on the porch and the four figures in various private uni-
forms being thought of as merely representative of the soldiers in the
investigation rather than striving to get 100% likenesses. I told him
this morning that a good likeness in profile would be impossible as
Kissinger probably has no memory of what he looked like at the time, nor
has anyone else (that is, from profile).

I am looking forward to receiving tomorrow a preliminary copy of
your speech which can be handed to press representatives in advance here
in New York City; also that you will bring fifty mimeographed copies with
you to Cleveland where I will meet you at the Hotel Cleveland on Sunday
morning.

As agreed on the 'phone, you will use the story about the old Wyeth
representative who spent his Sundays with your father as an impromptu in-
Dr Hench
-4-
May 28, 1941.
troductory story but not include it in the typed copy of your speech.
The newspapers will pick out the defense significance from your story
and possibly use it in the headline. Most of the copies of your speech
will be handed to newspaper representatives present by our Mr. Arthur L.
Greene, who is handling our newspaper contacts. He can explain the de-
fence angle to them.

I am sending invitations to Dr. and Mrs. Simpson and Dr. and Mrs.
Hench in Charlottesville, and also to your mother in Pittsburgh.

I am sorry that this whole affair has come on so rapidly and have
been such a drain on your time. It is just one of those things which
was conceived of rather late and has rapidly been built up to quite an
occasion. You may be sure that we appreciate your efforts and that they
will be appreciated by all those present. A preliminary story went out
last week and Mr. Greene tells me that the “New York Sunday Times” ran
it. How many other papers took it we don't know. I have not yet seen
a clipping. We have two clipping services, however, that worked on the
papers all over the United States, and they pick up practically every
line that appears.

I enclose a photograph showing the unfinished painting with Mr.
Cornwell and Col. C M. Walson, Second Corps Area Chief Medical Officer,
looking at the painting which was released with a second story to 150
newspapers for publication in Saturday and Sunday papers. I am sending
you a copy of this release as it will give you somewhat of an idea of
how far the painting had progressed last Friday when the photograph was
made. From this photograph it would appear to me that Cornwell had really
done a good likeness of Trudy, who is standing between Finlay and Agramonte.
The hands on the Reed figure have since been completed and the Lazear hand and
FinlayCarroll arm will be done in careful detail before the painting is shipped.
Cornwell remarked to me this morning that he could spend two weeks work-
ing on the shrubbery alone. This is a good story of which I think you
might make impromptu use. You note the whitewashed rocks along the path?
Last week when Cornwell was driving with some wealthy friends on Long
Island and there they passed a wall which had exactly the same type of
rocks which he needed in his painting He asked the chauffer to stop
and he hopped out and filched one of the rocks and brought it back into
the car. He remarked that his host and hostess were not overly pleased
but when I was in the studio yesterday I saw the 25-lb boulder on his
studio table.

I just talked with Mr. Cornwell's secretary a few minutes ago and
he is going to have the picture shipped to Cleveland tomorrow, Thursday
afternoon. He said he hoped to keep it until at least Saturday night
but the long holliday and union trucking regulations make that impossible.
If he did we might have to be an unveiling without any new picture and
we couldn't have that happen.
Dr. Hench

The photograph shows the painting at a considerable angle and does
not do it justice in the state that I saw it yesterday.

Please tell Mrs. Hench that I wrote her a postcard from Williams-
burg as I wanted to prove to her that I could write a postcard and re-
member to whom I sent it and what I had said.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, George A Kellogg GAK:L
